page.title: 06Culm Pyne Barton,Blackdowns
page.content: Culm Pyne Barton mentioned Domesday 1087 in Hemyock.Most of the land around Culm Davy was enclosed by 1837, the present large farmhouse and buildings date mainly from 1860 when agricultural prosperity was high, peaking about 1870.During all the depressed years the annual tythe payable to the established Church of England parson remained the same.It was a real burden for poor farmers to find actual cash specially during the pre1939 depression. The present owner commenced mixed farming in 1954 on 115 acres, the annual tythe was Â£25.Queen Anne's Bounty would redeem tythe for 10 times its value but Â£250 could not be afforded then. By 1975 all Tythes ceased on payment of 2 years value. Culm Pyne has one employed herdsman. Most Blackdown farms are inherited employing little outside labour.
